discourse_list.title: The case for payouts to token holders

content.content: Hi all, I’m sure this has been discussed before, but I couldn’t find a full answer. Please link me to it if it’s out there. I’ve been wondering: if we assume that the burn mechanic is the only method that there will ever be for returning value to MKR holders, what’s the ultimate point of holding MKR? I can think of a few arguments:   MKR tokens give you voting power. But why is this valuable?   You want to have a say in the mission of the protocol, e.g. “banking the unbanked” or “clean money”. But if we’re focusing on only financial value, this doesn’t provide any (directly).   If you control enough MKR, you can take over the protocol and give yourself all of the collateral. But this wouldn’t happen, because someone would trigger Emergency Shutdown and/or vault owners would withdraw their collateral if they observed it happening. The threat of these two (hopefully) deters a “51% attack” reason for MKR tokens having value.   So let’s set aside voting power as a reason for MKR having (financial) value.   Burning tokens increases the Earnings Per Share ratio.   But if there will never be a method for returning cold hard cash to holders (as opposed to buybacks), there’s really never going to be any “earnings” distributions, so really the EPS is 0 (or, conversely, P/E ratio is infinity). On the other hand, imagine the price of MKR does somehow go up. The amount of MKR we are able to buy and burn with our earnings as the price increases will decrease asymptotically — eventually we’ll literally just be burning our DAI for very little reduction in outstanding MKR supply / almost no increase in EPS.    Burning tokens increases buy-side pressure and so increases MKR price.   But the moment after we trade some DAI for MKR to burn, we are not worth more; we are worth the same, because we are down an equivalent amount of DAI. Here are a few articles on why buybacks only increase share price under specific circumstances:  The Dangers of Buybacks: Mitigating Common Pitfalls Do Share Buybacks Really Destroy Long-Term Value? Is a Share Buyback Right for Your Company?      The biggest reason buybacks have historically worked to increase share price is if management uses them wisely to signal to the market that the share price is undervalued.   But this would require us to:   Do large buybacks infrequently. From the last linked article above,  The materiality level shows, for different degrees of market mispricing, how large a buyback must be to have a significant effect on the share price. Small buybacks will have an effect only if the market heavily undervalues the shares. The common 5% buyback will hit the trigger materiality level of 5% only if the shares are trading at a 50% discount to their real value.    Not have a regular cadence for buybacks; instead we would have to agree (unlikely) on a model to price MKR, and then only do buybacks when the model indicates that we’re undervalued AND we have sufficient cash on hand to do a buyback that’s large enough to have an effect.       In summary, if there’s not even a possibility of cold hard cash being distributed to MKR holders in the distant future, what gives MKR value? Don’t we need some form of payout mechanism (even if we don’t turn it on for years), whether it’s dividend-style or sagittarius-engine-style or whatever? (I want to clarify that I’m not opposed to burning; I think some amount of burning is essential because MakerDAO isn’t an ordinary company and MKR tokens aren’t ordinary shares. MKR is the collateral-of-last-resort. Since flops are a crucial component of the system, flaps must exist as a counter-balance. The goal of flaps should be to give investors confidence that even if flops occur, the number of outstanding tokens will eventually come back down below some number, as it did after Black Thursday.) Thank you

content.content: The argument that i hear brought up time and time again regarding this always boils down to gas efficiency. My question here is would a direct dividend be viable on some L2 / EVM compatible chain or the other?

But my question is: without some direct payout mechanism in place, what’s the point of burning tokens at all (regardless of gas/tax efficiency)? Share buybacks only return value (under the right circumstances) because there is at least the possibility of dividends some day (even if it’s decades away). If there was no possibility of dividends ever, then shares would be worthless, no? If we decide that some payout mechanism is necessary to give MKR tokens value, then we can try to figure out a way to do it gas/tax efficiently, whether it’s L2 or sagittarius-style.

content.content: someone:  But the moment after we trade some DAI for MKR to burn, we are not worth more; we are worth the same, because we are down an equivalent amount of DAI . . In summary, if there’s not even a possibility of cold hard cash being distributed to MKR holders.   I think this part is more subtle and should be viewed from the MKR token holder’s point of view. You have to ultimately sell your MKR to get the cold hard cash - you just get more if you hold MKR for longer. The protocol needs to buy MKR in order to burn it and that must come from MKR holders. So at least one MKR holder gets DAI, which comes from the protocol’s earnings (stability fees minus protocol expenses). This is the part where an MKR holder gets cold hard cash. After such an event, there’s less MKR supply out there and the next time out, protocol needs to obtain MKR from the holders at a slightly higher price. Hence, any MKR holder who exchanges their MKR for DAI in this round gets a little more DAI than the first guy. Obviously, there are macro market movements that affect the price wildly but the burn mechanism keeps applying this buy pressure in the background which is why it’s worth holding MKR. The way this works is to drive the price of the token up and lets token holders decide when to realize those gains.

content.content: This explanation makes some sense to me, but it still feels a bit circular. Should I have to sell my tokens in order to profit? Wouldn’t an asset that also provides some value while being held (rather than only upon being sold) be more valuable? Perhaps part of the reason that MKR’s price lags behind other protocols that have far less profits is because of solely having an indirect, unproven, hard to understand mechanism for distributing them? Again, I think burning some tokens in important, but not having a direct payout mechanism in addition feels like we’re not maximizing the utility of the DAI we earn.

content.content: someone:  Wouldn’t an asset that also provides some value while being held (rather than only upon being sold) be more valuable?   Distributing protocol earnings to MKR holders directly would lower the burn rate so it doesn’t matter which mechanism you pick to transfer value. It is a zero sum game - all the protocol profits can only go to MKR holders one way or another. Of course, psychologically, people might react differently to a dividend-bearing token and that mechanism might be easier to understand. I wouldn’t say the burn mechanism is that indirect or hard to understand though. Finally, there are also lots of benefits to not having payouts. For example, it is more gas efficient by not having those payout transactions. It is also preferable in many jurisdictions to have your gains be taxed as capital gains than dividend income.

content.content: AstronautThis:  It is a zero sum game - all the protocol profits can only go to MKR holders one way or another.   Can you provide any reading on this? I’m not convinced that it is a zero-sum game — different methods of payouts would seem to have different efficiencies (even apart from gas/tax). To my knowledge, Maker is one of the first experiments ever at solely having buybacks without any direct payout mechanism to provide a rationale for them. The articles I linked above suggest that even buybacks under different circumstances have different efficiencies at returning value to holders, so it’s hard to imagine mechanisms as different as buybacks and dividends are completely equivalent.     AstronautThis:  Finally, there are also lots of benefits to not having payouts. For example, it is more gas efficient by not having those payout transactions. It is also preferable in many jurisdictions to have your gains be taxed as capital gains than dividend income.   Perhaps we can figure out a sagittarius-style (i.e., profits are able to be withdrawn as an interest-free loan against locked MKR) way of retaining the tax/gas benefits of buybacks while also providing direct cash, while also retaining the benefits of partial burning and reducing MKR supply. Thank you for your responses!
